title: Interview questions
text:
I’ve spent the last decade at the intersection of data science and the built environment. Early on, I realized that while infrastructure is static, human behavior is dynamic. This led me to the Space Syntax approach—essentially using data-driven, graph-based analysis to understand multi-scale networks. It allowed me to bridge the gap between rigorous academic theory and the practical realities of urban consultancy.
In terms of technical scale, my experience is quite broad. I’ve managed everything from high-frequency IoT sensor data for real-time indoor movement to architecting the tracking of entire city bus networks modelling scenarios. I’ve applied these insights to everything from local ‘urban acupuncture’ strategies to large-scale masterplans, always focusing on how we can use data to measure social benefits. My work has taken me across the globe—from Colombia to Australia, London, and now Madrid—which has given me a deep appreciation for the cultural nuances required to work effectivily with multinational teams.
Inevitably, working on European urban development leads you to the Net-Zero agenda. Most recently, in 2024, I led a team of eight researchers at the Norman Foster Institute to develop the Climate Action Plan for Athens. This was a major milestone where we had to harmonize environmental data,set plans for reaching carbon emission targets, and greening strategies into a compliant, actionable policy framework.
This work led me to what I call my ‘professional obsession’: the link between environmental quality and human health outcomes. I’ve realized that the environment—whether it’s air quality, climate resilience, or the built landscape—is the primary driver of health inequalities. Over the last year, I’ve been focusing on quantifying these links, moving from spectral analysis of country-wide information to advising on transport initiatives that prioritize health outcomes. I want to move beyond just ‘collecting data’ to reducing the environmental inequalities that impact people’s lives.
That brings me here. I see this role at the EEA as the ideal next frontier. It’s the one place where I can combine data at scale, health implications, and European policy. I’ve spent my career ‘forcing’ these elements to meet, and I’m eager to bring that integrated perspective to the Agency’s monitoring and evidence-gathering mission.



There are three primary reasons why I am sitting here today, ranging from the Agency’s unique mandate to the urgency of our current environmental timeline.

The Unique Intersection of Science and Policy First, from an institutional perspective, the EEA is unparalleled. There is truly no other organization in the world where high-level science, legislative policy, and ground-level implementation meet with such a rigorous and independent point of view. For a data professional, the opportunity to work within the Eionet framework—translating raw monitoring data into the evidence base that literally steers the European Green Deal—is the highest possible application of my skillset.
The Urgency of the Mission Second, on a personal level, I cannot think of a human challenge more pressing than the climate and biodiversity crisis. We saw in the State of the Environment Report (SOER) that while our frameworks are robust, far too few of our targets are currently on track for 2030. This reality doesn’t discourage me; it focuses me. I want to be part of the ‘course correction,’ using data to identify exactly where we are lagging and how we can accelerate progress toward climate neutrality.
The Scale of the Challenge Finally, I am genuinely excited by the sheer scale of the challenge. Moving from urban-scale projects to a pan-European monitoring mandate is a significant leap, but it is one I feel prepared for. I am at a stage in my career where I want to contribute at the highest level possible. I am confident that my experience in harmonizing fragmented data across borders and my focus on health outcomes can provide the Agency with the ‘connective tissue’ needed to turn complex monitoring into actionable policy insights.




I view stress not as an individual burden to be hidden, but as a signal to recalibrate our collective focus. My approach to high-pressure situations—such as a tight reporting deadline for a major EEA indicator—is built on three pillars:

Above all, I am a team player. When pressure mounts, I believe in absolute transparency with my peers. I don’t ‘hide’ from the stress; I bring it to the table so we can address it together. By fostering a supportive environment early on, I ensure that when a crisis hits, the team feels comfortable speaking up about bottlenecks before they become failures.
(‘Project First’ Mindset) My first instinct in a stressed scenario is to shift the focus from individual tasks to the overall project objective. I lead the team in a rapid prioritization exercise—identifying ‘must-haves’ versus ‘nice-to-haves’ and playing to each person’s strengths. It’s an ‘all hands on deck’ approach where we reallocate resources dynamically to ensure the core mission is met, even if it means shifting secondary individual goals.
(Proactive Mentorship and Support Networks) I am a firm believer in keeping close mentors and a professional support network. I don’t wait for a crisis to build these relationships. By maintaining regular contact with mentors, I have a ‘ready-to-go’ sounding board when stress hits. This means I can get high-level advice or a second opinion quickly, without needing a full debrief of the situation, allowing for faster decision-making under pressure.

In short, I manage stress by converting it into structured team action. This ensures that the quality of our evidence remains high, even when the timeline is short.



I’ve had a very rewarding journey in my current position, and I am proud of the milestones our team has achieved. However, I have reached a professional ceiling where the nature of the work no longer aligns with where I want to make an impact. I am moving toward this role for three main reasons:

Moving from Advice to Implementation and Tracking In consultancy, you often advise up to a certain point, but because there is sometimes a lack of regulatory follow-through on proposals, it is difficult to ensure those suggestions have a sustained, long-term life. I no longer want to just ‘drop’ a project and move to the next; I want to be part of an institution that has the mandate for the long-term monitoring and tracking of those initiatives. I want to see the evidence loop close.
Seeking a Long-Term Institutional Vision I am looking for a professional environment with a 10- or 20-year horizon, rather than a 6-month project cycle. The EEA’s mission to provide the evidence base for the European Green Deal offers that stability and vision. I want to dedicate my skills to one cohesive, long-term plan where the data I architect today informs policy assessments a decade from now.
Giving Back and Team Growth I leave my current role on excellent terms. I’ve learned an immense amount, built lasting professional relationships, and found great fulfillment in up-skilling my colleagues and mentoring junior researchers. However, to continue my own growth as an expert in environmental health and data architecture, I need to be in a place where the scale of the challenge matches the scale of the European mission.

Closing Statement: Essentially, I’m not running away from my current role; I am running toward the responsibility and the long-term accountability that comes with being an Expert at the EEA.
Here is your consolidated EEA Interview Cheat Sheet. This Markdown is designed to be your “Source of Truth.” You can print this out or keep it on a secondary screen during your interview to ensure your narrative hits every institutional and technical requirement.





The Journey: Architect (Bogotá) → Space Syntax/Networks (UCL/London) → Geospatial Data Architect (Global).
The Languages: Spanish (Native), English (Fluent), French (Fluent), Portuguese (Advanced). Key for Eionet coordination.
The Pivot: Shifting focus to Environmental Health (prevention over cure) and linking urban morphology to climate resilience.
The “Why”: Transitioning from Consultancy (Advising) to EEA (Shaping/Implementing). I want to contribute to the “Gold Standard” of European data and help “Course Correct” the 2030 Climate Action Plan.
The Stack: Reportnet 3.0 (Modern, cloud-native reporting), Copernicus Land Monitoring Service (CLMS), and the SDI (Spatial Data Infrastructure).
Key Themes: Human Health & Environment; Circular Economy; Data & Digitalization.

Moved from “green city” goals to data-driven Nature-Based Solutions.

Managed “Gold Standard” pipeline for 160 countries.
Data Harmonization: Translated noisy human reports into a clean SQL database.

Proved ability to scale-up from city-level to country-wide (Colombia).

Integrated TfL, Thames Water, & ARUP data.
Consensus Building: Acted as the technical translator between conflicting agency standards.







Strength 1: Bilingual Technical Literacy. (I speak “Coder” and “Policy”).
Strength 2: High-Volume Orchestration. (Experience with large-scale, country-wide data).
Strength 3: Interdisciplinary Vision. (Linking transport, environment, and health outcomes).
Weakness 1: Independence over Delegation. Correction: I’ve adopted “Time-boxing”; if I can’t solve it in 2 hours, I reach out to the team for collective efficiency.
Weakness 2: Routine Motivation. Correction: I use Automation. Instead of doing mundane tasks manually, I build Python scripts to handle the repetition.
Weakness 3: Communication Density. Correction: I use “Top-Down” communication. Policy impact first, technical details (Neural Networks/Graph Theory) only if requested.

“Closing the implementation gap” (helping countries report better)
“LCZ (Local Climate Zones)” (for heat island analysis)
“Life-cycle of data management”
“Knowledge Exchange” (treating Eionet as a two-way street)

title: Course Guide
text:
Content
This course introduces students to the concepts, technologies, governance models, and socio-spatial implications of Smart Cities. It critically examines how digital technologies, data, and urban analytics are applied to address urban challenges such as sustainability, mobility, climate adaptation, inclusion and quality of life. Through a project-based approach, students work in groups to analyse a real or simulated urban case, develop a Smart Cities solution, and reflect on ethical, social and governance dimensions. In this course, the student will gain fundamental theoretical and practical knowledge to understand smart cities, including the relationship to the sustainability debate applies knowledge and skills to a real-life case study involving local communities in the indicator analysis, development of Smart City planning solutions and policy recommendations for the built environment. Be able to critically reflect on Smart City concepts and communicate the results of Smart City strategies to stakeholders. This course utilises acquired knowledge from previous and parallel running courses, such as the advanced methods course, ethics in research, data analysis in GIS, and urban policies, and adds to it the component of smart sustainable cities and the human factor.



Course Coordinator:
Prof. Claudia van der Laag

title: Systems Thinking
text:
Session Roadmap


Part I: The Landscape of Urban Complexity

The “Brain” of the Smart City & 4 Heuristics

Part II: The Logics of Systems

Deep Dive into Feedback Loops
Workshop I: Mapping Your Wicked Problem

Part III: Decision Support Tools

Workshop II: Stakeholders and Data





Start by managing expectations: Today we move from theory to logic to practice.
Part I is the ‘Why’ (Complexity) and the ‘How’ (The 4 Heuristics). It sets the conceptual stage.
Part II is the ‘Deep Dive’. We get hands-on with System Dynamics logic to help them deconstruct the specific course assignments they are working on.
Part III links the “Brain” back to reality: How does this logic serve stakeholders and talk to data?

title: Systems Thinking
text:
The City = Complex System

A city is decomposable into predictable parts.
It is a dynamic process of organized complexity.
The Smart City Paradox: * We have new technical capabilities (Big Data, sensors, AI).

But they rely on modelling techniques devised decades ago to solve social problems.




The city is the ultimate complex system.
“Smart” doesn’t mean “New.” Many of the algorithms we use today were born in the 1960s and 70s to address social housing, transport equity, and urban decay. The technology has caught up to the theory, but the focus remains social.

title: Systems Thinking
section: What the Smart City is NOT
text:
What the Smart City is NOT

It is not a crystal ball for perfect prediction.
It is not a digital twin that is the reality.
The Map is not the Territory:

Models are simplified representations.
In a complex system, “Total Control” is an illusion.
We model to understand potentiality, not to dictate outcomes.




models are fallible.
Because of urban complexity (non-linearity and emergence), we can’t predict exactly what a city will do.
“The Answer,” they are misrepresenting what a model is. It’s a tool for exploration, not a decree.

title: Systems Thinking
text:
The Science of Cities



“[…] cities must now be looked at as constellations of interactions, communications, relations, flows, and networks rather … than locations […] location is, in effect, a synthesis of interactions.”





Michael Batty, 2017

title: Systems Thinking
text:
The “Wicked” Problem

Urban challenges are not puzzles (with one right answer).
They are Wicked Problems:

They are interconnected: solving one creates another.
They have no “stopping rule” or perfect solution.
They are better or worse, not right or wrong.



Refer to Rittel and Webber’s definition. Explain that in a smart city context, we often try to “optimize” things. But a city isn’t a machine to be optimized; it’s a wicked problem to be managed. For their assignments: help them see that their chosen problem (e.g., housing or pollution) is “wicked” because it’s tied to a dozen other factors.

title: Systems Thinking
text:
The “Brain” of the Smart City

The Back-end (Today): The heuristics, logic, and models.
The Front-end (Next Lecture): Dashboards, visualizations, and stakeholder apps.
The Principle: Logic must precede display.


Use the “Brain” analogy to ground the lecture. The “Front-end” is what people see (the dashboard), but the “Brain” is the modeling logic we are discussing today. If the logic (the model) is flawed, the visualization is just “fancy misinformation.” Today is about building the intellectual back-end.

title: Systems Thinking
text:
Systems Thinking 101

Linear Thinking: A \(\rightarrow\) B (Cause and Effect).
Systems Thinking: Seeing the Web of interactions.
Focus on the relationships between parts, not just the parts themselves.


Contrast the two ways of thinking. Linear thinking says: “Traffic is bad, widen the road.” Systems thinking asks: “If I widen the road, how does that change land use, and how does that eventually bring more cars back (induced demand)?” This is the fundamental shift required for the rest of the lecture.

title: Systems Thinking
text:
Modeling as a Heuristic

A model is not “The Truth.”
It is a Heuristic: a mental shortcut or tool for discovery.
“All models are wrong, but some are useful” (George Box).


This is a friendly way to lower the “technical” barrier. You aren’t asking them to be data scientists today; you are asking them to use models as “thinking tools” to simplify a reality that is too complex to hold in their heads all at once.
